title: Highest Government Expenditure as a Percentage of GDP
description: In 2022, Kiribati's general government final consumption expenditure was 61.53% of its GDP, the highest globally, indicating a significant government role in the economy.

title: Leading in Final Consumption Expenditure
description: Kiribati's final consumption expenditure reached 162.39% of GDP in 2022, the highest in the world, reflecting a high level of consumption relative to its economic output.

title: Top Gross National Expenditure
description: In 2022, Kiribati's gross national expenditure was 182.69% of GDP, the highest globally, suggesting a significant reliance on external financial resources.

title: High Government Investment in Education
description: Kiribati allocated 14.20% of its GDP to education in 2021, ranking among the highest in the world, highlighting a strong commitment to educational development.

title: High Female Mortality from Non-Communicable Diseases
description: In 2021, 37.8% of females in Kiribati aged 30-70 faced mortality from CVD, cancer, diabetes, or CRD, one of the highest rates globally, indicating significant health challenges.

title: High Male Mortality from Non-Communicable Diseases
description: Kiribati reported a 51.1% mortality rate for males aged 30-70 from CVD, cancer, diabetes, or CRD in 2021, one of the highest globally, highlighting critical health issues.

title: High Overall Mortality from Non-Communicable Diseases
description: In 2021, 44.1% of Kiribati's population aged 30-70 faced mortality from CVD, cancer, diabetes, or CRD, ranking among the highest worldwide, pointing to severe health concerns.

title: High Youth Unemployment and Inactivity
description: In 2020, 53.67% of Kiribati's youth were not in education, employment, or training, one of the highest rates globally, indicating significant challenges in youth engagement.

title: High Male Youth Unemployment and Inactivity
description: 51.58% of male youth in Kiribati were not in education, employment, or training in 2020, one of the highest rates globally, reflecting challenges in male youth engagement.

title: Lowest Methane Emissions from Transport
description: In 2023, Kiribati recorded a minimal methane emission from transport, amounting to just 0.0001 Mt CO2e, showcasing its low environmental impact in this sector.

title: Minimal Personal Remittances Paid
description: Kiribati's personal remittances paid in 2023 were among the lowest globally, totaling $1,542,579.77, indicating limited outbound financial support.

title: Negligible New Business Registrations
description: In 2018, only 2 new businesses were registered in Kiribati, reflecting a challenging environment for entrepreneurship.

title: Lowest Fixed Telephone Subscriptions
description: With just 26 fixed telephone subscriptions in 2023, Kiribati ranks among the lowest globally, highlighting limited telecommunication infrastructure.

title: Minimal External Balance on Goods and Services
description: Kiribati's external balance on goods and services was -85.01% of GDP in 2023, indicating a significant trade deficit.

title: Lowest Gross Domestic Savings
description: In 2022, Kiribati's gross domestic savings were -62.39% of GDP, reflecting a high consumption rate relative to income.

title: Minimal International Tourism Receipts
description: In 2020, Kiribati earned just $30,000 from international tourism receipts, highlighting its limited tourism sector.

title: Lowest Merchandise Exports to South Asia
description: In 2019, Kiribati's merchandise exports to South Asia were virtually nonexistent, at 0.00003% of total exports.
